text: PREKINDERGARTEN
label: H4

label: H4

label: H4

label: H4

text: For nearly 40 years, the federal
label: BODY

text: government has played a role in
label: BODY

text: providing early childhood
label: BODY

text: development programs for children
label: BODY

text: of low-income families through
label: BODY

text: Head Start and other programs.
label: BODY

text: Since 1980, the number of states
label: BODY

text: with preschool programs has also
label: BODY

text: significantly increased. While most
label: BODY

text: of these programs have targeted
label: BODY

text: children at risk of school failure,
label: BODY

text: more recently, interest has grown
label: BODY

text: in expanding these limited
label: BODY

text: programs because of the growing
label: BODY

text: concern about children’s readiness
label: BODY

text: for school and subsequent
label: BODY

text: achievement. It has also been
label: BODY

text: fueled by new research on early
label: BODY

text: brain development that suggests
label: BODY

text: the importance of early education
label: BODY

text: and by the high rate of mothers in
label: BODY

text: the workforce and their need for
label: BODY

text: early childhood services. In this
label: BODY

text: context, questions have arisen
label: BODY

text: about how the various programs
label: BODY

text: are coordinated and what lessons
label: BODY

text: have been learned from broad-
label: BODY

text: based state preschool efforts.
label: BODY

text: This work focused on four states
label: BODY

text: that have expanded their preschool
label: BODY

text: programs to serve more children.
label: BODY

text: In these states, GAO addressed (1)
label: BODY

text: how prekindergarten programs
label: BODY

text: were designed and funded, (2) the
label: BODY

text: potential implications of these
label: BODY

text: program features for children’s
label: BODY

text: participation and other programs
label: BODY

text: that serve four year-olds, and (3)
label: BODY

text: the outcome data that have been
label: BODY

text: collected on participating children
label: BODY

text: and families. To gather this
label: BODY

text: information, GAO conducted site
label: BODY

text: visits in four states—Georgia, New
label: BODY

text: Jersey, New York, and Oklahoma.
label: BODY

text: The expanded prekindergarten programs in Georgia, Oklahoma, New York,
label: BODY

text: and New Jersey had some similarities in their design features. For instance,
label: BODY

text: programs were offered at no direct cost to parents, regardless of family
label: BODY

text: income, and each state incorporated some level of collaboration with
label: BODY

text: community-based providers such as Head Start and large child care facilities.
label: BODY

text: Some key differences in their design features also existed. For example,
label: BODY

text: Georgia and Oklahoma had statewide programs providing prekindergarten
label: BODY

text: services to over half of their four-year olds, while New York’s and New
label: BODY

text: Jersey’s programs were more geographically targeted. States and school
label: BODY

text: districts also varied in offering full- or half-day prekindergarten programs.
label: BODY

text: States also varied in teacher qualifications, the percentage of
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten children served by community-based providers, funding
label: BODY

text: methods, and in the amount of funding per child.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Some program features had potential implications for the participation of
label: BODY

text: children and for early childhood programs. For example, none of the four
label: BODY

text: states required providers to transport all children to and from
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten, and many children were enrolled in half-day programs,
label: BODY

text: which officials believed might have limited the participation of children from
label: BODY

text: low-income and working families. Collaborations between programs and
label: BODY

text: community-based organizations generally permitted rapid program
label: BODY

text: expansion and were viewed as beneficial to early childhood programs.
label: BODY

text: Finally, we found few data to determine the impact of state prekindergarten
label: BODY

text: expansion on the availability or prices of child care.
label: BODY

text: While some data were available on outcomes for children who participated
label: BODY

text: in prekindergarten programs, less was known about their impacts on
label: BODY

text: families. For example, a study in Oklahoma showed that children who
label: BODY

text: participated made significant gains on several school readiness measures
label: BODY

text: relative to a comparison group of unenrolled children. However, none of the
label: BODY

text: four states had measured effects on families, such as parents’ work effort.

text: The Honorable Edward M. Kennedy
label: BODY

text: Ranking Minority Member
label: BODY

text: The Honorable Jack Reed

text: United States Senate
label: BODY

text: For nearly 40 years, the federal government has played a role in providing
label: BODY

text: early childhood development programs for children of low-income
label: BODY

text: families through Head Start and other programs. Prior to 1970, only a few
label: BODY

text: states had prekindergarten programs, and these were mostly available to a
label: BODY

text: small number of children and targeted specific populations such as
label: BODY

text: disadvantaged children, those at risk of school failure, or those with
label: BODY

text: special needs. More recently, there has been interest in expanding these
label: BODY

text: limited prekindergarten programs because of the growing concern about
label: BODY

text: children’s readiness for school and subsequent achievement. This interest
label: BODY

text: has also been fueled by advances in early brain development research that
label: BODY

text: suggest the importance of early education and by the high rate of mothers
label: BODY

text: in the workforce and their need for early childhood services. During the
label: BODY

text: 2001-02 school year, about 40 states enrolled approximately 700,000 of the
label: BODY

text: nation’s 7.8 million three- and four-year-olds in prekindergarten programs,
label: BODY

text: and spent over $2.4 billion to finance these programs. A few of these states
label: BODY

text: have invested significant resources to expand enrollments of
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten programs beyond targeted populations. They have also
label: BODY

text: used federal funds such as Title I of the Elementary and Secondary
label: BODY

text: Education Act, as amended by the No Child Left Behind Act of 2001, and
label: BODY

text: Individuals with Disabilities Education Act to support prekindergarten
label: BODY

text: programs, and have implemented these programs in a variety of settings
label: BODY

text: such as child care centers and Head Start agencies, as well as public
label: BODY

text: schools.
label: BODY

text: United States Government Accountability Office
label: BODY

text: Washington, DC 20548
label: BODY

text: Page 2
label: BODY

text: GAO-04-852  State Prekindergarten Programs
label: BODY

text: Given the level of investment and the variety of preschool programs
label: BODY

text: currently receiving federal and state support, there is concern about
label: BODY

text: whether these programs are well coordinated and that lessons from
label: BODY

text: implementing broadly based state programs are documented. Accordingly,
label: BODY

text: you asked that we review programs in selected states that expanded their
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten efforts. This report presents information on (1) how state
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten programs were designed and funded in these states,
label: BODY

text: (2) the potential implications of these program features for children’s
label: BODY

text: participation and for other programs that serve four-year-olds, and (3) the
label: BODY

text: outcome data that have been collected on participating children and
label: BODY

text: families.
label: BODY

text: To determine how prekindergarten programs were designed, we reviewed
label: BODY

text: program information and interviewed state officials, local education
label: BODY

text: program officials, as well as numerous Head Start grantees and directors
label: BODY

text: of large child care facilities, during site visits to four states (Georgia, New
label: BODY

text: Jersey, New York, and Oklahoma). These states were selected, in part,
label: BODY

text: because they were among a small subset of states that had expanded their
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten programs and aimed to serve all four-year-olds whose
label: BODY

text: parents wanted them to attend, regardless of family income. We also
label: BODY

text: considered states that had well-established prekindergarten programs.
label: BODY

text: Because New Jersey had two major preschool programs, including the
label: BODY

text: court-ordered Abbott program that was implemented in New Jersey’s 30
label: BODY

text: highest-poverty school districts, we report on a total of five
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten programs in four states.
label: BODY

text: To identify potential implications of the design of state prekindergarten
label: BODY

text: programs, we interviewed (1) state and local education agency officials;
label: BODY

text: (2) providers of prekindergarten services at community-based
label: BODY

text: organizations; and (3) federal, state, and local Head Start program staff.
label: BODY

text: We also reviewed selected data on child care availability in these states
label: BODY

text: and the nation. We assessed the data for reliability and reasonableness and
label: BODY

text: found them to be sufficiently reliable for the purposes of this report. To
label: BODY

text: determine what outcome data have been collected on participating
label: BODY

text: children and families, we interviewed state and local education agency
label: BODY

text: officials in each of the four states we visited, contacted researchers, and
label: BODY

text: reviewed two studies—a study of a school district in Oklahoma and one
label: BODY

text: statewide study in Georgia. We assessed the methodologies used in these
label: BODY

text: studies and determined that the methodologies were of sufficient quality
label: BODY

text: for use in discussion of most study findings, and we limited our discussion
label: BODY

text: to these findings. (App. I contains a more detailed discussion of our scope
label: BODY

text: and methodology.) We conducted our work between October 2003 and
label: BODY

text: Page 3
label: BODY

text: GAO-04-852  State Prekindergarten Programs
label: BODY

text: August 2004 in accordance with generally accepted government auditing
label: BODY

text: standards.
label: BODY

text: The four states we visited had developed expanded prekindergarten
label: BODY

text: programs that varied in design features and funding. The four states’
label: BODY

text: program features were similar in that each offered services at no direct
label: BODY

text: costs to parents and emphasized preparing children for school and
label: BODY

text: preventing failure in early grades. They also afforded the option of
label: BODY

text: collaboration with community-based providers. We found significant
label: BODY

text: differences in other aspects of the programs, such as geographic coverage,
label: BODY

text: requirements for teachers, and extent of reliance on community-based
label: BODY

text: providers of early childhood education. For example, Georgia had a
label: BODY

text: statewide program that was implemented in all of its school districts,
label: BODY

text: while New Jersey targeted its two prekindergarten programs in high-
label: BODY

text: poverty areas—covering about 24 percent of its school districts. Teacher
label: BODY

text: qualifications also varied among the four states. Requirements for lead
label: BODY

text: teachers ranged from an associate’s degree to a bachelor’s degree with
label: BODY

text: certification in early childhood education. In providing their
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten programs, states and school districts also differed in the
label: BODY

text: degree and type of collaborations they established with community-based
label: BODY

text: providers such as Head Start and private child care centers. In terms of
label: BODY

text: funding, the four states relied primarily on state resources but differed in
label: BODY

text: funding methods and amounts per child. For example, New York financed
label: BODY

text: its program using general revenues, while Georgia relied on proceeds from
label: BODY

text: a state lottery. With regard to funding levels, New Jersey had the highest
label: BODY

text: funding per child for its Abbott prekindergarten—over $9,500 compared
label: BODY

text: with less than $4,200 for each of the other programs during the 2002-03
label: BODY

text: school year. All four states generally used relatively small amounts of
label: BODY

text: federal funds, such as those from Title I or the Individuals with Disabilities
label: BODY

text: Education Act, to support their prekindergarten programs.
label: BODY

text: Some design features of state prekindergarten programs had potential
label: BODY

text: implications for children and early childhood programs in the four states
label: BODY

text: we visited. For example, both local officials and providers told us that the
label: BODY

text: lack of transportation and half-day programs may have affected
label: BODY

text: participation in prekindergarten programs for children of low-income and
label: BODY

text: working families. None of the four states we visited required
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten providers to transport all participating children.
label: BODY

text: Regarding the implications of state prekindergarten programs for other
label: BODY

text: early childhood program providers, three of the five programs served most
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten children through community-based organizations such as
label: BODY

text: Head Start and child care centers. State and local officials and community-
label: BODY

text: based providers told us that collaborations were beneficial to their
label: BODY

text: Results in Brief
label: H4

text: Page 4
label: BODY

text: GAO-04-852  State Prekindergarten Programs
label: BODY

text: programs, but they also identified some challenges. In terms of benefits,
label: BODY

text: some states used collaborations to quickly expand their prekindergarten
label: BODY

text: programs by using existing age-appropriate facilities. In addition,
label: BODY

text: collaborations increased access to school district resources for some
label: BODY

text: community-based organizations. Some Head Start grantees received state
label: BODY

text: funds to provide prekindergarten services, while other grantees told us
label: BODY

text: they had begun serving more three-year-olds to offset the loss of four-year-
label: BODY

text: olds who participated in state prekindergarten programs elsewhere, which
label: BODY

text: potentially increased the number of poor children with 2 years of
label: BODY

text: preschool education. At the same time, challenges remained for some
label: BODY

text: states and school districts—including the lack of expertise in arranging
label: BODY

text: formal contracts and maintaining effective collaborations with
label: BODY

text: community-based providers. Little empirical data were available to
label: BODY

text: determine the degree to which these broad-based state prekindergarten
label: BODY

text: programs affected the availability of and prices for child care, and the
label: BODY

text: anecdotal evidence we collected was mixed.
label: BODY

text: Some data have been collected on outcomes for participating children, but
label: BODY

text: little is known about outcomes for their families. In the school districts we
label: BODY

text: visited, we found that assessments of children’s development were
label: BODY

text: incorporated in the curriculum and used to provide information to parents.
label: BODY

text: We also found two studies that provided information about the
label: BODY

text: educational outcomes of state prekindergarten programs in Oklahoma and
label: BODY

text: Georgia. A study conducted by Georgetown University collected data on
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten children in the Tulsa, Oklahoma, school district and found
label: BODY

text: that children who participated in the Tulsa program had significantly
label: BODY

text: higher scores on several school readiness measures than similar children
label: BODY

text: in the comparison group, who did not participate in the Tulsa
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten program. A second study, conducted by Georgia State
label: BODY

text: University on Georgia’s prekindergarten program, reported that children
label: BODY

text: who participated in the state program made significant gains on several
label: BODY

text: school readiness measures, including language and problem solving, as did
label: BODY

text: children in Head Start and those enrolled in private prekindergarten
label: BODY

text: programs. None of the four states we visited reported collecting
label: BODY

text: information regarding the impact of their programs on families with
label: BODY

text: respect to issues such as workforce participation.
label: BODY

text: The growth in state prekindergarten programs has occurred for various
label: BODY

text: reasons, but three frequently cited reasons are (1) evidence of the
label: BODY

text: importance of early childhood to later development, (2) the high rate of
label: BODY

text: labor force participation by mothers of young children, and (3) increased
label: BODY

text: concern over school readiness and subsequent achievement. Much has
label: BODY

text: Background
label: H4

text: Page 5
label: BODY

text: GAO-04-852  State Prekindergarten Programs
label: BODY

text: been discovered about children’s ability to learn more at an earlier age
label: BODY

text: than previously believed. The early childhood years are commonly
label: BODY

text: portrayed as formative. Between the first day of life and the first day of
label: BODY

text: kindergarten, development proceeds at a pace exceeding that of any
label: BODY

text: subsequent stage of life. Children from birth to age five engage in making
label: BODY

text: sense of the world on many levels: language, human interactions, counting
label: BODY

text: and quantification, spatial reasoning, physical causality, problem solving,
label: BODY

text: and categorization.
label: BODY

text: Since the 1960s, the percentage of women in the labor force has increased
label: BODY

text: dramatically. In 1960, about 36 percent of women participated in the labor
label: BODY

text: force, and by 2000 this figure had increased to 58 percent. Moreover, in
label: BODY

text: 2003, about 69 percent of women with children aged three to five (but
label: BODY

text: none younger) were in the labor force. This high rate of participation of
label: BODY

text: women in the labor force has resulted in more children enrolled in
label: BODY

text: preschool programs of varying quality and pressure being placed on
label: BODY

text: schools to provide before- and after-school programs.
label: BODY

text: To improve educational achievement for all children and reduce failure in
label: BODY

text: lower grades, many states and school districts are placing a greater
label: BODY

text: emphasis on the school readiness of younger children. For nearly a quarter
label: BODY

text: century, many states have developed or expanded their investment in
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten programs to increase the likelihood of children’s success
label: BODY

text: in school. Prior to 1970 only 7 states funded preschool programs, and by
label: BODY

text: 1988, 28 states had programs and total spending was $190 million;
label: BODY

text: 2 such
label: BODY

text: programs generally targeted economically and educationally
label: BODY

text: disadvantaged children. While most state-sponsored prekindergarten
label: BODY

text: programs continue to serve such children, a few states are in the process
label: BODY

text: of expanding their programs to include all four-year-olds, regardless of
label: BODY

text: family income. According to the National Institute for Early Education
label: BODY

text: Research (NIEER), 40 states (and Washington, D.C.) had some form of
label: BODY

text: state-sponsored prekindergarten program in the 2001-02 school year and

label: BODY

text: enrolled over 700,000 children, mostly four-year-olds.
label: BODY

text: 3 While states spent
label: BODY

text: more than $2.4 billion for prekindergarten during the 2001-02 school year,
label: BODY

text: 10 states accounted for over 80 percent of this amount.
label: BODY

text: Generally, prekindergarten programs aimed to serve four-year-olds, but
label: BODY

text: according to NIEER estimates, most states served less than one-fifth of all
label: BODY

text: their four-year-olds (see fig. 1). NIEER estimated that about 80 percent of
label: BODY

text: In addition to administering Head Start, the federal government also
label: BODY

text: provides some limited support for early education programs through Title
label: BODY

text: I. Administered by the Department of Education (Education), Title I is the
label: BODY

text: single largest federal investment for elementary and secondary education.
label: BODY

text: Its primary purpose is to help local education agencies and schools
label: BODY

text: improve the teaching and learning of children who are failing, or are most
label: BODY

text: at risk of failing, to meet challenging academic standards. In support of
label: BODY

text: that goal, Education reported that Title I was funded at about $11.7 billion
label: BODY

text: during the 2003 fiscal year. Nearly 15 million students were supported by
label: BODY

text: Title I funds, and of these, about 2 percent (an estimated 313,000) were
label: BODY

text: enrolled in prekindergarten programs during the 1999-2000 school year.
label: BODY

text: The Child Care and Development Fund (CCDF) is the principal federal
label: BODY

text: program that supports child care for low-income families. CCDF is
label: BODY

text: administered by HHS, and each state receives an annual allocation that is
label: BODY

text: used to subsidize the child care expenses of low-income families with
label: BODY

text: children generally under age 13. CCDF subsidies can be used to obtain
label: BODY

text: child care from various types of providers, including child care centers
label: BODY

text: 6Education also funds two other smaller early childhood education-related initiatives. The
label: BODY

text: Even Start program was designed to improve family literacy and educational opportunities.
label: BODY

text: The program is generally targeted to parents who are not enrolled in school and their
label: BODY

text: children through age seven, who lack a high school diploma or its equivalent; the basic
label: BODY

text: skills necessary to function in society; or are unable to speak, read, or write English. In
label: BODY

text: program year 2000, Even Start served about 31,600 families and 41,600 children; in 2002,
label: BODY

text: Even Start was funded at $250 million. Early Reading First is a competitive grant program
label: BODY

text: to support local efforts to enhance the early language, literacy, and prereading
label: BODY

text: development of preschool age children, particularly those from low-income families,
label: BODY

text: through strategies and professional development that are based on scientifically based
label: BODY

text: reading research. In fiscal year 2003, nearly $75 million was awarded to 30 grantees.

text: The four states we visited varied in the design features and funding of their
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten programs. Programs shared similar features such as
label: BODY

text: voluntary enrollment of children at no direct cost to their parents, but
label: BODY

text: differed in others. In addition, all five state programs permitted
label: BODY

text: collaboration with community-based providers. States varied in features
label: BODY

text: such as the teacher requirements for their prekindergarten programs.
label: BODY

text: States and school districts also differed in the degree and type of
label: BODY

text: collaborations they established with community-based agencies. Finally,
label: BODY

text: while states relied primarily on state resources, they reported some
label: BODY

text: differences in funding mechanisms and per child funding levels.
label: BODY

text: In the four states visited—Georgia, New Jersey, New York, and
label: BODY

text: Oklahoma—we found some similarities in prekindergarten programs.
label: BODY

text: Over the last few years, all four states had expanded their state-sponsored
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten programs and, as reported by NIEER in February 2004,
label: BODY

text: were among only nine states and Washington, D.C., that provided
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten services to more than 20 percent of their four-year-olds.
label: BODY

text: All four states’ prekindergarten programs were provided at no direct cost
label: BODY

text: to parents—regardless of family income—and were offered on a voluntary
label: BODY

text: basis; children’s enrollment was not mandatory. In addition, each program
label: BODY

text: emphasized preparation for school and incorporated the delivery of

text: living in the 30 highest-poverty school districts in the state receive a high-quality preschool
label: BODY

text: education. The New Jersey Department of Education funds a 6-hour, 180-day
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten program, and the New Jersey Department of Human Services funds a
label: BODY

text: wraparound program that provides daily before- and after-care and a summer program. In
label: BODY

text: total, the full-day, full-year program is available to eligible children for 10 hours per day,
label: BODY

text: 245 days per year. The New Jersey Department of Education reported that during the 2002-
label: BODY

text: 03 school year, the Abbott program enrolled nearly 36,500 children at a cost of about $347
label: BODY

text: million for prekindergarten. An official of the New Jersey Department of Human Services
label: BODY

text: also reported that about $103 million was spent for the wraparound services during the
label: BODY

text: 2003 fiscal year. In addition, school districts can opt to have a 3-hour-per-day program for
label: BODY

text: 20 days over the summer break. This program would also be funded by the state
label: BODY

text: Department of Education.

text: Per child expenditures for full-day and half-day prekindergarten varied
label: BODY

text: across the four states we visited and were consistently less than the state’s
label: BODY

text: per pupil expenditures for kindergarten through grade 12. New Jersey’s
label: BODY

text: Abbott districts had the highest funding per child for full-day
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten, relative to kindergarten through grade 12 funding.
label: BODY

text: 16 In the
label: BODY

text: remaining states, funding for full-day prekindergarten was much less than
label: BODY

text: the level of funding per child in kindergarten through grade 12. See figure
label: BODY

text: 3 for comparisons of per child expenditures for prekindergarten and
label: BODY

text: kindergarten through grade 12 in the four states we visited.
label: BODY

text: 16While New Jersey’s Abbott prekindergarten program per child funding was more than
label: BODY

text: double the other state programs, certain aspects of the program contributed to the
label: BODY

text: increased costs. For example, one feature (maximum class size) increased program cost by
label: BODY

text: roughly 25 percent by limiting enrollment to 15 children. The New Jersey Department of
label: BODY

text: Education also initiated a number of activities to improve program quality. For example,
label: BODY

text: during the 2002-03 school year, the state provided a year-long training program for 105
label: BODY

text: master teachers who, in turn, mentored and coached over 4,000 classroom teachers and
label: BODY

text: assistant teachers in the Abbott school districts. The New Jersey Department of Education
label: BODY

text: also recommended that the Abbott school districts employ one family worker for every 45
label: BODY

text: students. Family workers are to meet regularly with teachers and families to identify
label: BODY

text: specific concerns or needs, assist in locating resources in the community, and support
label: BODY

text: families in utilizing these resources.

text: GAO-04-852  State Prekindergarten Programs
label: BODY

text: The four states varied in how they funded their state-sponsored
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten programs, and officials in two states told us that the
label: BODY

text: financial outlook of their programs was stable. According to two
label: BODY

text: New Jersey state officials, because of the state supreme court decision and
label: BODY

text: subsequent court order, New Jersey was committed to providing a quality
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten program to all three- and four-year-olds who lived in the
label: BODY

text: Abbott school districts. In addition, funding for both New Jersey’s Abbott
label: BODY

text: and non-Abbott ECPA prekindergarten programs was part of the school
label: BODY

text: funding formula. Oklahoma supported prekindergarten through the
label: BODY

text: funding formula, as it did for other school grades, and state officials told
label: BODY

text: us they believed that funding for the program was stable.
label: BODY

text: However, funding for prekindergarten in the other two states may be more
label: BODY

text: uncertain. For example, funding levels for New York’s state-sponsored
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten had increased somewhat for the past 3 years but were
label: BODY

text: insufficient to allow the state to implement a universal prekindergarten
label: BODY

text: program available to all four-year-olds by the 2001-02 school year as
label: BODY

text: planned. During the same period, New York financed its program from
label: BODY

text: general revenue funds as a line item in the budget, and in 2003, the
label: BODY

text: program was targeted for elimination because of state fiscal shortfalls.
label: BODY

text: While avoiding elimination, limited increases in funding have restricted the
label: BODY

text: state’s ability to expand the program over the past several years. Most
label: BODY

text: eligible districts participated in the program. However, about two-thirds of
label: BODY

text: the school districts were not eligible for the state-sponsored
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten program during the 2002-03 school year.
label: BODY

text: Georgia has historically relied on the state lottery to fund its
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten program. When the lottery was initially created, its
label: BODY

text: proceeds were set aside for three programs, including state-sponsored
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten. Currently, lottery funds are used to support
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten and a program to provide academic scholarships for
label: BODY

text: eligible high school graduates. However, over time, a greater percentage of
label: BODY

text: the lottery funds has been designated for the college scholarship program
label: BODY

text: than for prekindergarten. Additionally, lotteries recently began in two
label: BODY

text: neighboring states, and officials we interviewed were concerned that
label: BODY

text: Georgia’s lottery proceeds may level off. State officials told us that lottery
label: BODY

text: funds may be insufficient to entirely support the prekindergarten program
label: BODY

text: by 2007, and the state has begun to look at stop gap measures to protect
label: BODY

text: lottery funding if needed in the future.
label: BODY

text: The four states reported using small amounts of federal funds to support
label: BODY

text: their prekindergarten programs; these amounts were generally small
label: BODY

text: relative to state funding levels. For example, two states—Georgia and
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Oklahoma—used some prekindergarten monies to meet their CCDF
label: BODY

text: matching or maintenance-of-effort requirements.

text: 17 In fiscal year 2002,
label: BODY

text: Georgia used about $2.4 million in lottery funds for CCDF state matching
label: BODY

text: and maintenance-of-effort, which represented about 1 percent of the state
label: BODY

text: funding for prekindergarten. These funds were used for extended day
label: BODY

text: (before- and after-school) for Temporary Assistance for Needy Families
label: BODY

text: (TANF) eligible children participating in prekindergarten. Oklahoma used
label: BODY

text: about $2.1 million of its prekindergarten funds to meet CCDF
label: BODY

text: maintenance-of-effort requirements, which represented about 3 percent of
label: BODY

text: the state funding for prekindergarten. In fiscal year 2002, New York
label: BODY

text: transferred $61.3 million from the TANF program to the state
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten program, but this was done for only one year.
label: BODY

text: 18 None of
label: BODY

text: the other states used TANF funds to support the expansion of their
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten programs. While state officials told us that Title I,
label: BODY

text: Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, and Head Start program funds
label: BODY

text: were also used at the local level to support prekindergarten, they did not
label: BODY

text: know the exact amounts from these other federal sources.
label: BODY

text: 17States receive CCDF funds from potentially four funding streams. Each state’s annual
label: BODY

text: federal allocation consists of separate discretionary, mandatory, and matching funds. A
label: BODY

text: state does not have to obligate or spend any state funds to receive the discretionary and
label: BODY

text: mandatory funds. However, to receive federal matching funds—and thus its full CCDF
label: BODY

text: allocation—a state must maintain its program spending at a specified level, referred to as a
label: BODY

text: state’s maintenance of effort, and spend additional state funds above that level.
label: BODY

text: 18TANF, a block grant to states, provides temporary assistance to needy families. In
label: BODY

text: general, able-bodied TANF recipients, who receive cash assistance, must participate in
label: BODY

text: work or work-related activities after receiving assistance for a maximum of 24 months, and
label: BODY

text: there is a 5-year lifetime limit on federal assistance. Beyond work, work-related activities
label: BODY

text: include education and training; job search; and participation in community service. States
label: BODY

text: may also use a portion of TANF funds for child care services.

text: GAO-04-852  State Prekindergarten Programs
label: BODY

text: Some prekindergarten design features had implications for children’s
label: BODY

text: participation and early childhood programs in the four states we visited.
label: BODY

text: For example, both local officials and providers told us that transportation
label: BODY

text: and program hours may have affected access to prekindergarten programs
label: BODY

text: for children of low-income and working families. State and local officials,
label: BODY

text: along with community-based providers and Head Start grantees, told us
label: BODY

text: that collaborations were beneficial to their programs and had allowed
label: BODY

text: rapid expansion of state prekindergarten. However, some challenges
label: BODY

text: remained, such as the efforts needed to establish and maintain effective
label: BODY

text: collaborations. Finally, few empirical data were available to quantify the
label: BODY

text: effect of expanding state prekindergarten programs on the availability and
label: BODY

text: prices for child care, and the anecdotal evidence we collected was mixed.
label: BODY

text: Program features, which varied across states and school districts, may
label: BODY

text: have affected participation, particularly for children of low-income and
label: BODY

text: working families. None of the four states required prekindergarten
label: BODY

text: providers to transport all participating children. Officials in some school
label: BODY

text: districts told us that the lack of transportation may have decreased the
label: BODY

text: participation of children from low-income and working families, and 10 of
label: BODY

text: the 12 school districts we visited did not provide transportation to and
label: BODY

text: from prekindergarten for all participating children. Some school district
label: BODY

text: officials primarily cited insufficient funding as a reason for not providing
label: BODY

text: transportation services. For example, in one Oklahoma school district,
label: BODY

text: children did not necessarily attend prekindergarten classes at their
label: BODY

text: neighborhood school; consequently, the district would have incurred
label: BODY

text: additional costs to transport children to their designated school. One
label: BODY

text: official in a rural school district we visited in New York told us that more
label: BODY

text: children from low-income and working families would have participated in
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten if transportation were provided. However, costs
label: BODY

text: prohibited the district from offering such services. However, officials in
label: BODY

text: the urban school district we visited in New York did not view the lack of
label: BODY

text: transportation as a barrier to participation, as the prekindergarten
label: BODY

text: programs were generally available in proximity to children’s homes or
label: BODY

text: parents’ jobs. In Georgia, the Department of Early Care and Learning
label: BODY

text: offered additional funding to providers who opted to transport eligible
label: BODY

text: children to and from the prekindergarten program.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Citing benefits of prekindergarten, many states have made an investment
label: BODY

text: in the early education of young children, especially four-year-olds.
label: BODY

text: Georgia, New Jersey, New York, and Oklahoma have taken steps to
label: BODY

text: expand early educational opportunities for preschoolers. These four states
label: BODY

text: offer different approaches for consideration by other states that are
label: BODY

text: considering whether to expand the scope of their prekindergarten
label: BODY

text: programs. Given that states have limited resources, an opportunity exists
label: BODY

text: to engage community-based providers such as Head Start grantees and
label: BODY

text: other early education and care providers in the coordinated delivery of
label: BODY

text: additional prekindergarten services. Collaborations between school
label: BODY

text: districts and community-based organizations facilitate the coordination of
label: BODY

text: child care and early learning for preschoolers and can provide additional
label: BODY

text: classroom capacity. At the same time, these partnerships can help allay
label: BODY

text: fears among child care providers that prekindergarten programs would
label: BODY

text: supplant the need for community-based services.
label: BODY

text: It is also important to acknowledge the trade-offs of certain program
label: BODY

text: features. For example, while programs with limited hours may
label: BODY

text: accommodate a higher number of children within the same facility and
label: BODY

text: may be less likely to affect existing child care providers, they may create
label: BODY

text: barriers to participation for children of working families and show smaller
label: BODY

text: effects in school readiness of children. Also, prekindergarten programs
label: BODY

text: may benefit by collaborating with existing programs to maximize the
label: BODY

text: efficient use of limited state and federal education resources. However,
label: BODY

text: such arrangements may make it necessary for states and school districts
label: BODY

text: to invest resources to facilitate such coordination. Perhaps the biggest
label: BODY

text: trade-off that states face is whether the benefits of an expanded

label: H4

text: Page 33

text: GAO-04-852  State Prekindergarten Programs
label: BODY

text: In conducting our review, we obtained and analyzed information from the
label: BODY

text: federal Departments of Education and Health and Human Services, state
label: BODY

text: agencies,
label: BODY

text: 1 and local education agencies (LEA). We visited four states, and
label: BODY

text: in each state we interviewed staff from state agencies and LEAs, and
label: BODY

text: generally included one urban, one suburban, and one rural school district
label: BODY

text: in each state—for a total of 12 school districts. We also interviewed early
label: BODY

text: childhood education and child care policy experts and reviewed selected
label: BODY

text: current literature on state-sponsored prekindergarten programs.
label: BODY

text: For our fieldwork, we considered states that (1) had expanded programs
label: BODY

text: and aimed to serve all children whose families wanted them to attend, (2)
label: BODY

text: served large numbers of children in their prekindergarten programs, and
label: BODY

text: (3) had well-established programs. We attempted to include varied
label: BODY

text: program models and gave some priority to states that had studied their
label: BODY

text: efforts.
label: BODY

text: To determine how states designed their prekindergarten programs, we
label: BODY

text: interviewed state and local education officials and officials of 13
label: BODY

text: community-based organizations who were direct providers of state
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten services. We also reviewed documents related to states’
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten programs, including state laws, general program
label: BODY

text: information, state data on program participation and costs, curriculum
label: BODY

text: guides, content standards, and contracts governing collaborations with
label: BODY

text: community-based organizations. We obtained information to describe the
label: BODY

text: state-sponsored prekindergarten programs and reviewed the data for
label: BODY

text: reasonableness. We assessed reliability of specific information, including
label: BODY

text: estimates of age-eligible children and program expenditures, by
label: BODY

text: interviewing state officials in all four states about their data reliability
label: BODY

text: assessment processes. On the basis of this information, we concluded that
label: BODY

text: the data were sufficiently reliable for the purposes of this report. In
label: BODY

text: addition, we performed a detailed review of the methodology of a National
label: BODY

text: Institute for Early Education Research report and found it to be sufficient
label: BODY

text: for descriptive purposes. The data that were used for background
label: BODY

text: purposes were not independently verified.
label: BODY

text: To determine the potential implications of prekindergarten on other
label: BODY

text: programs that serve four-year-olds, we interviewed state child care
label: BODY

text: 1In New Jersey, New York, and Oklahoma, we collected information and interviewed
label: BODY

text: officials from the state education agencies (SEA); in Georgia, we collected information and
label: BODY

text: interviewed officials from the Department of Early Care and Learning, which administered
label: BODY

text: the prekindergarten program.
label: BODY

text: Appendix I: Scope and Methodology
label: H2

text: Appendix I: Scope and Methodology
label: H4

text: Page 34
label: BODY

text: GAO-04-852  State Prekindergarten Programs
label: BODY

text: administrators, state and local Head Start association directors,
label: BODY

text: coordinators and program staff, as well as staff of local child care centers.
label: BODY

text: We also met with national and state representatives of the National Child
label: BODY

text: Care Association (an association of managers and owners of child care
label: BODY

text: centers) and related organizations, as well as state and local staff of child
label: BODY

text: care resource and referral offices. We also reviewed selected national and
label: BODY

text: state data on child care availability and prices. Finally, we interviewed
label: BODY

text: state officials regarding federal funds, including Title I of the Elementary
label: BODY

text: and Secondary Education Act, Temporary Assistance for Needy Families,
label: BODY

text: Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, and the Child Care and
label: BODY

text: Development Block Grant. We did not review the expenses of providers of
label: BODY

text: state prekindergarten services to ascertain the extent, if any, to which
label: BODY

text: federal funds or other revenues may have subsidized provision of
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten.
label: BODY

text: To determine what is known about the impacts of prekindergarten
label: BODY

text: programs on children and families in the states visited, we interviewed
label: BODY

text: state and local education officials and local policy experts. We also
label: BODY

text: identified two studies on children’s outcomes that met our selection
label: BODY

text: criteria: studies that (1) analyzed student achievement and (2) compared
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten children with a control or comparison group of children
label: BODY

text: who did not attend the state-sponsored prekindergarten programs.
label: BODY

text: 2 To
label: BODY

text: collect information systematically, we developed a data collection
label: BODY

text: instrument and examined each study to assess the adequacy of the
label: BODY

text: samples and measures employed, the reasonableness and rigor of the
label: BODY

text: statistical techniques used to analyze them, and the validity of the results
label: BODY

text: and conclusions that were drawn from the analyses. A social scientist read
label: BODY

text: and coded the documentation for each study. A second social scientist
label: BODY

text: reviewed each completed data collection instrument and the relevant
label: BODY

text: documentation to verify the accuracy of every coded item. We found these
label: BODY

text: two studies to be sufficiently reliable and rigorous to include in our report.
label: BODY

text: 2We identified a third study, the Rochester Early Childhood Assessment Partnership 2002-
label: BODY

text: 2003 Annual Report, but did not review the study because it did not include comparison
label: BODY

text: groups and thus could not isolate the potential effects of New York’s universal
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten program on the children who attended.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: We did not identify any studies that assessed the impact of these
label: BODY

text: prekindergarten programs on working families such as workforce
label: BODY

text: participation.
label: BODY

text: We conducted our work between October 2003 and August 2004 in
label: BODY

text: accordance with generally accepted government auditing standards.
